trans-unit.source: Network client security

seg-source.mrk: Network client security

target.mrk: Network client security

trans-unit.source: The <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Client allows you to select a security mechanism by specifying a value for the <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> property.

seg-source.mrk: The <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Client allows you to select a security mechanism by specifying a value for the <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> property.

target.mrk: The <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Client allows you to select a security mechanism by specifying a value for the <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> property.

trans-unit.source: Network Client security

seg-source.mrk: Network Client security

target.mrk: Network Client security

trans-unit.source: You can set the <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> property in one of the following ways:

seg-source.mrk: You can set the <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> property in one of the following ways:

target.mrk: You can set the <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> property in one of the following ways:

trans-unit.source: When you are using the <codeph>DriverManager</codeph> interface, set <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> in a <codeph>java.util.Properties</codeph> object before you invoke the form of the <codeph>getConnection</codeph> method, which includes the <codeph>java.util.Properties</codeph> parameter.

seg-source.mrk: When you are using the <codeph>DriverManager</codeph> interface, set <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> in a <codeph>java.util.Properties</codeph> object before you invoke the form of the <codeph>getConnection</codeph> method, which includes the <codeph>java.util.Properties</codeph> parameter.

target.mrk: When you are using the <codeph>DriverManager</codeph> interface, set <codeph>securityMechanism</codeph> in a <codeph>java.util.Properties</codeph> object before you invoke the form of the <codeph>getConnection</codeph> method, which includes the <codeph>java.util.Properties</codeph> parameter.

trans-unit.source: When you are using the <codeph>DataSource</codeph> interface to create and deploy your own DataSource objects, invoke the <codeph>DataSource.setSecurityMechanism</codeph> method after you create a DataSource object.

seg-source.mrk: When you are using the <codeph>DataSource</codeph> interface to create and deploy your own DataSource objects, invoke the <codeph>DataSource.setSecurityMechanism</codeph> method after you create a DataSource object.

target.mrk: When you are using the <codeph>DataSource</codeph> interface to create and deploy your own DataSource objects, invoke the <codeph>DataSource.setSecurityMechanism</codeph> method after you create a DataSource object.

trans-unit.source: The following table lists the security mechanisms that the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Client supports, and the corresponding property value to specify to obtain this security mechanism. The default security mechanism is the user id only if no password is set. If the password is set, the default security mechanism is both the user id and password. The default user is APP if no other user is specified.

seg-source.mrk: The following table lists the security mechanisms that the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Client supports, and the corresponding property value to specify to obtain this security mechanism.
The default security mechanism is the user id only if no password is set.
If the password is set, the default security mechanism is both the user id and password.
The default user is APP if no other user is specified.

target.mrk: The following table lists the security mechanisms that the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Client supports, and the corresponding property value to specify to obtain this security mechanism.
The default security mechanism is the user id only if no password is set.
If the password is set, the default security mechanism is both the user id and password.
The default user is APP if no other user is specified.

target.mrk: <codeph>ClientDataSource.ENCRYPTED_USER_AND_PASSWORD_SECURITY</codeph> (0x09)

trans-unit.source: Encryption requires a JCE implementation that supports the Diffie-Hellman algorithm with a public prime of 256 bits.

seg-source.mrk: Encryption requires a JCE implementation that supports the Diffie-Hellman algorithm with a public prime of 256 bits.

target.mrk: Encryption requires a JCE implementation that supports the Diffie-Hellman algorithm with a public prime of 256 bits.

trans-unit.source: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> provides three ClientDataSource implementations. You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource</codeph> class on Java SE 5 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 3 or JDBC 4.0 methods. You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 6 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 4.1 or JDBC 4.2 methods. You must use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.BasicClientDataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 8 Compact Profile 2 or 3.

seg-source.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> provides three ClientDataSource implementations.
You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource</codeph> class on Java SE 5 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 3 or JDBC 4.0 methods.
You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 6 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 4.1 or JDBC 4.2 methods.
You must use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.BasicClientDataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 8 Compact Profile 2 or 3.

target.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> provides three ClientDataSource implementations.
You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource</codeph> class on Java SE 5 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 3 or JDBC 4.0 methods.
You can use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 6 and above (except Java SE 8 Compact Profiles), in applications that call JDBC 4.1 or JDBC 4.2 methods.
You must use the <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.BasicClientDataSource40</codeph> class on Java SE 8 Compact Profile 2 or 3.
